title: EUROCORES LogiCCC: collaboration led by Kleiter. Thinking about counterfactual possibilities in middle-childhood
abstractText:
When we miss trains or have to work late to meet a deadline, thoughts of how the world might have been otherwise often come to us. These are called counterfactual thoughts. This research will explore counterfactual thinking by children aged 5- to 9- years-old. There are two key developments:

  1. Holding in mind multiple possibilities. At around 5 years children understand that an event in the past could have possibly turned out differently.
  2. Comparisons between possibilities. Later between 7 and 9 years, children start to understand counterfactual emotions, such as regret and relief. These emotions rely on a comparison between reality and what could have happened.

The relation between these developments and basic cognitive processes will be investigated using simple tasks that tap different aspects of childrenâ€™s reasoning ability, language abilities and their executive functioning: working memory (holding information in mind), attention shifting (switching between ideas), and inhibitory control (ignoring irrelevant information).

The aim is to combine these results with those from a previous ESRC project to provide a comprehensive cognitive developmental account of counterfactual thinking in 3- to 9- year olds.
impactText: Our results have informed further studies of children's and adults' cognition. In particular they have underpinned an ESRC transformative Social Sciences grant on cognition in middle childhood and they have informed work on counterfactual thinking in brain damaged patients.
findingsText:
Our main findings were:
1) That children's experience of regret was related to their attentional switching
2) That we found no relationship with working memory, nor any effect of the number of possibilities involved in the task Our research will inform further work on counterfactuals and regret in decision making. Education
